citation.fr: [{\"type\": \"dataset\", \"id\": \"ca.cioos_36ca073e-b6fb-422a-9f7f-e9e31eff8207\", \"author\": [{\"given\": \"Cassandra\", \"family\": \"Hartery\"}, {\"given\": \"Frederick\", \"family\": \"Whoriskey\"}, {\"given\": \"Martha J\", \"family\": \"Robertson\"}], \"issued\": [{\"date-parts\": [\"2025\", \"03\", \"24\"]}], \"abstract\": \"Ce projet de recherche collaboratif utilisera la t\u00e9l\u00e9m\u00e9trie acoustique et satellitaire pour d\u00e9terminer quand, o\u00f9 et pendant combien de temps des saumons de l'Atlantique de trois stades de vie diff\u00e9rents (saumoneaux, kelts retournant en mer pour se remettre en forme et adultes hivernaux multimarins) vivent dans les r\u00e9gions extrac\u00f4ti\u00e8res de l'est du Canada (r\u00e9gions 8 \u00e0 15 du Fonds d'\u00e9tudes environnementales [FEE]) pr\u00e9sentant un int\u00e9r\u00eat pour l'exploitation p\u00e9troli\u00e8re et gazi\u00e8re afin d'\u00e9clairer la prise de d\u00e9cisions r\u00e9glementaires et le d\u00e9veloppement de projets futurs. Ce projet de recherche a \u00e9t\u00e9 \u00e9labor\u00e9 et est mis en \u0153uvre en collaboration avec les Premi\u00e8res Nations et des partenaires du milieu universitaire, du secteur des ONG, du gouvernement et du public. Le projet est dirig\u00e9 par le minist\u00e8re des P\u00eaches et des Oc\u00e9ans (Martha Robertson, chercheuse principale). Les r\u00e9sultats contribueront de mani\u00e8re significative \u00e0 notre compr\u00e9hension actuellement limit\u00e9e de la fa\u00e7on dont le saumon de l'Atlantique utilise les zones marines au large de l'est du Canada et appuieront la prise de d\u00e9cisions fond\u00e9es sur des preuves et l'\u00e9laboration conjointe de meilleures pratiques op\u00e9rationnelles afin de minimiser les impacts n\u00e9gatifs potentiels des activit\u00e9s p\u00e9troli\u00e8res et gazi\u00e8res sur le saumon de l'Atlantique.\", \"edition\": \"\", \"edition-date\": \"\", \"publisher\": \"\", \"title\": \"FEE - Projet de suivi du saumon de l'Atlantique - Ocean Drifters\", \"language\": \"fr\", \"URL\": \"https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset/ca-cioos_36ca073e-b6fb-422a-9f7f-e9e31eff8207?local=fr\"}]
citation.en: [{\"type\": \"dataset\", \"id\": \"ca.cioos_36ca073e-b6fb-422a-9f7f-e9e31eff8207\", \"author\": [{\"given\": \"Cassandra\", \"family\": \"Hartery\"}, {\"given\": \"Frederick\", \"family\": \"Whoriskey\"}, {\"given\": \"Martha J\", \"family\": \"Robertson\"}], \"issued\": [{\"date-parts\": [\"2025\", \"03\", \"24\"]}], \"abstract\": \"This collaborative research project will use acoustic and satellite telemetry to determine when, where and for how long Atlantic salmon from three different life stages (post-smolt, kelts returning to sea to recondition, and multi-sea winter adults) are in the Eastern Canadian offshore regions (Environmental Studies Research Fund [ESRF] Regions 8 to 15) of interest for oil and gas development to inform regulatory decision-making and future project development. This research project has been developed and is being implemented collaboratively with First Nations and partners from academia, the NGO sector, government and the public. The project is led by the Department of Fisheries and Oceans (Martha Robertson, Principal Investigator). Results will contribute significantly to our currently limited understanding of how Atlantic salmon use the marine areas off Eastern Canada and support evidence-based decision making and co-development of best operational practices to minimize potential adverse impacts of oil and gas activities on Atlantic salmon.\", \"edition\": \"\", \"edition-date\": \"\", \"publisher\": \"\", \"title\": \"ESRF - Atlantic Salmon Offshore Tracking Project - Ocean Drifters\", \"language\": \"en\", \"URL\": \"https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset/ca-cioos_36ca073e-b6fb-422a-9f7f-e9e31eff8207?local=en\"}]

      <mri:abstract xsi:type="lan:PT_FreeText_PropertyType">
        <gco:CharacterString>This collaborative research project will use acoustic and satellite telemetry to determine when, where and for how long Atlantic salmon from three different life stages (post-smolt, kelts returning to sea to recondition, and multi-sea winter adults) are in the Eastern Canadian offshore regions (Environmental Studies Research Fund [ESRF] Regions 8 to 15) of interest for oil and gas development to inform regulatory decision-making and future project development. This research project has been developed and is being implemented collaboratively with First Nations and partners from academia, the NGO sector, government and the public. The project is led by the Department of Fisheries and Oceans (Martha Robertson, Principal Investigator). Results will contribute significantly to our currently limited understanding of how Atlantic salmon use the marine areas off Eastern Canada and support evidence-based decision making and co-development of best operational practices to minimize potential adverse impacts of oil and gas activities on Atlantic salmon.</gco:CharacterString>

name: ca-cioos_36ca073e-b6fb-422a-9f7f-e9e31eff8207
notes: This collaborative research project will use acoustic and satellite telemetry to determine when, where and for how long Atlantic salmon from three different life stages (post-smolt, kelts returning to sea to recondition, and multi-sea winter adults) are in the Eastern Canadian offshore regions (Environmental Studies Research Fund [ESRF] Regions 8 to 15) of interest for oil and gas development to inform regulatory decision-making and future project development. This research project has been developed and is being implemented collaboratively with First Nations and partners from academia, the NGO sector, government and the public. The project is led by the Department of Fisheries and Oceans (Martha Robertson, Principal Investigator). Results will contribute significantly to our currently limited understanding of how Atlantic salmon use the marine areas off Eastern Canada and support evidence-based decision making and co-development of best operational practices to minimize potential adverse impacts of oil and gas activities on Atlantic salmon.

description_translated.en:
CIOOS-Atlantic is a consortium of partner institutions which are committed to the development of a data management and dissemination approach for oceanographic data from the Atlantic Seaboard, a region spanning from Labrador to the Maine / New Brunswick border.

Meaningful engagement and ongoing communication with a broad variety of stakeholders is an integral component of CIOOS-Atlantic, and we will work to meet the needs of the local oceanographic community and ensure regional interests are represented at the national level. Emphasis is placed on the creation of a system which promotes easy data access and supports the work of partners, researchers, industry, and more.
